      161. Ruch, W., & Ekman, P. (2001). The expressive pattern of laughter. In A. W. Kaszniak (Ed.), Emotion, Qualia, and Consciousness (pp. 426-443). Tokyo: Word Scientific Publisher.Google Scholar
      162. Russell, J. A. (1980). A circumplex model of affect. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 39, 1161-1178.Google ScholarCross Ref
      163. Russell, R. E. (2000). Humor's close relatives. Humor-International Journal of Humor Research, 13(2), 219-233.Google ScholarCross Ref
      164. Rutter, J. (2000). The stand-up introduction sequence: comparing comedy comperes. Journal of Pragmatics, 32(4), 463-483.Google ScholarCross Ref
      165. Sacks, H. (1974). The analysis of the course of a joke's telling in conversation. In R. Bauman & J. Sherzer (Eds.), Explorations in the Ethnography of Speaking (pp. 337-353). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.Google Scholar
      166. Sacks, H. (1995). Lectures on Conversation. Volume 1&2. Cambridge, MA: Blackwell.Google Scholar
      167. Sandweg, N., Hassenzahl, M., & Kuhn, K. (2000). Designing a telephone-based interface for a home automation system. International Journal of Human-Computer Interaction, 12(3-4), 401-414.Google ScholarCross Ref
      168. Saul, J. R. (1997). The Unconscious Civilization. New York: The Free Press.Google Scholar
      169. Schachter, S., & Singer, J. (1962). Cognitive, social and physiological determinants of emotional state. Psychological Review, 63, 379-399.Google ScholarCross Ref
      170. Schmitt, B. H. (1999). Experiential Marketing. New York: The Free Press.Google Scholar
      171. Schwartz, S. H., & Bilsky, W. (1987). Toward a Universal Psychological Structure of Human-Values. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 53(3), 550-562.Google ScholarCross Ref
      172. Schwartzman, H. (1978). Transformations: The Anthropology of Children's Play. New York: Plenum.Google Scholar
      173. Seifert, K., Baumgarten, T., Kuhnt, T., & Hassenzahl, M. (2001). Multimodale mensch-computer-interaktion: tool oder gimmick? In K.-P. Timpe, R. Marzi, V. Karavezyris, & H.-H. Erbc (Eds.), Bedienen und Verstehen. 4. Berliner Werkstatt Mensch-Maschine Systeme (pp. 275-291). Dusseldorf: VDI-Verlag.Google Scholar
      174. Self, W. (1994). My idea of fun. London: Penguin books.Google Scholar
      175. Seligman, M. E. P., & Csikszentmihalyi, M. (2000). Positive psychology: an introduction. American Psychologist, 55, 5-14.Google ScholarCross Ref
      176. Shneiderman, B. (1987). Designing the User Interface: Strategies for Effective Human-Computer Interaction. Reading, MA: Addison-Wesley. Google Scholar
      177. Skynner, R., & Cleese, J. (1993). Life And How To Survive It. London: Methuen.Google Scholar
      178. Slater, D. (1998). Work/leisure. In C. Jenks (Ed.), Core Sociological Dichotomies (pp. 391-404). London: Sage Publications Ltd.Google Scholar
      179. Smith, D. C., & A., C. (1999). Making programming easier for children. In A. Druin (Ed.), The Design of Children's Technology (pp. 201-222). San Francisco: Morgan Kaufmann. Google Scholar
      180. Solso, R. (1999). Cognition and the Visual Arts. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press. Google Scholar
      181. Sonnentag, S. (1996). Work group factors and individual well-being. In M. A. West (Ed.), Handbook of Work Group Psychology (pp. 345-367). Chichester: John Wiley & Sons.Google Scholar
      182. Springel, S. (1999). The new media paradigm: users as creators of content. Personal Technologies, 3, 153-159.Google ScholarCross Ref
      183. Stephenson, W. (1967). The Play Theory of Mass Communication. New Brunswick, NJ: Transaction Publishers.Google Scholar
      184. Stone, M., Fishkin, K., & Bier, E. (1994). The movable filter as a user interface tool, pp. 306-312, CHI '94 Proceedings, Boston, Massachusetts. Google Scholar
      185. Strasser, S. (1982). Never Done: A History of American Housework. New York: Pantheon Books.Google Scholar
      186. Sutton-Smith, B. (1988). Introduction to the transaction edition. In W. Stephenson (Ed.), The Play Theory of Mass Communication. New Brunswick, NJ: Transaction Publisher.Google Scholar
      187. Taylor, A., & Harper, R. (2002). Age-old Practices in the 'New World': a study of gift-giving between teenage mobile phone users, pp. 439-446, CHI 2002 Proceedings, Minneapolis, MN. Google Scholar
      188. Thackara, J. (2000). Edge effect: the design challenge of pervasive interface, CHI 2000 Plenary presentation, Seattle, WA. Google ScholarDigital Library
      189. Thompson, E. P. (1963). The Making Of The English Working Class. London: Gollancz.Google Scholar
      190. Tractinsky, N., Katz, A. S., & Ikar, D. (2000). What is beautiful is usable. Interacting With Computers, 13(2), 127-145.Google ScholarCross Ref
      191. Tufte, E. R. (1984). The Visual Display of Quantitative Information. Chesire, Conneticut: Graphics Press. Google Scholar
      192. Turkle, S. (1995). Life on the Screen: Identity in the Age of the Internet. London: Phoenix. Google Scholar
      193. Veatch, T. C. (1998). A theory of humor. Humor-International Journal of Humor Research, 11(2), 161-215.Google ScholarCross Ref
      194. Viegas, A., & Donath, C. (1999). Chat circles, pp. 306-312, CHI '99 Proceedings, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Google Scholar
      195. Vogel, H. L. (1998). Entertainment Industry Economics. (Fourth ed.). Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.Google Scholar
      196. Vygotsky, L. S. (1998). Imagination and creativity in childhood. In R. W. Rieber (Ed.), The Collected Works of L.S. Vygotsky. New York: Plenum.Google Scholar
      197. Webster, J., & Ho, H. (1997). Audience engagement in multimedia presentations. Data Base For Advances in Information Systems, 28(2), 63-77. Google ScholarDigital Library
      198. Wensveen, S. A. G., Overbeeke, C. J., & Djajadiningrat, J. P. (2002). Push me, shove me and I show you how you feel: recognising mood from emotionally rich interaction, pp. 335-340, DIS 2002 Proceedings, London. Google Scholar
      199. Williams, R. (1998). Erving Goffman. In R. Stones (Ed.), Key Sociological Thinkers (pp. 151-162). London: Macmillan Press Ltd.Google Scholar
      200. Willis, P. (1990). Common Culture: Open University Press.Google Scholar
      201. Willis, P. (2000). The Ethnographic Imagination. Cambridge: Polity Press.Google Scholar
      202. Wilson, S. (2002). Information Arts: Intersections of Art, Science and Technology. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press.Google Scholar
      203. Winograd, T. (1986). Understanding Computers and Cognition. Norwood, NJ: Ablex. Google Scholar
      204. Winograd, T. (1996). Bringing Design to Software. New York, NY: Addison-Wesley. Google Scholar
      205. Zajone, R. B. (1965). Social facilitation. Science, 149, 269-274.Google ScholarCross Ref
      206. Ziv, A. (1988). Teaching and learning with humor: experiment and replication. Journal of Experimental Education, 57(1), 5-15.Google ScholarCross Ref
      207. Zizek, S. (1999). The fantasy in cyberspace. In E. Wright (Ed.), The Zizek Reader. Oxtbrd: Blackwell.Google Scholar
      208. Zsambok, C. E. (1997). Naturalistic decision making: where are we now? In C. E. Zsambok & G. Klein (Eds.), Naturalistic Decision Making. Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum.Google Scholar
